awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is a novel, inexpensive, and environmentally friendly solution for production improvement in oil, gas, geothermal, and groundwater reservoirs. Fracking/stimulation is a required step after drilling to increase permeability and get access to the trapped geofluid in sedimentary and rock formations. This method provides an alternative or complimentary reservoir permeability enhancement solution to current high-pressure water/acid injection-based method such as hydraulic or acid fracking. This proposed innovation will allow for an economical permeability increase without water contamination and induced seismic activities. Furthermore, this method will alleviate the demand in water stressed areas.

This I-Corps project will identify the commercial potential for developing a novel Electric Reservoir Stimulation (ERS) method that increases reservoir permeability for petroleum and geothermal applications, without requiring pumping material into the subsurface. This method will consist of controlled high voltage electrical pulses applied in two electrodes placed at the depth of interest between wells. In this method, the conductivity of the geofluid along with the pulse discharge parameters (amplitude, width, frequency), and treatment time will determine the effect on the permeability of the reservoir rock. Fluid mobility is increased due to viscosity reduction and reservoir permeability is increased in the direction of interest from the vibrational removal of particles within pores. We're performing experimental analysis in our lab on different core samples to see the effects of the proposed electric treatment. Additionally, numerical simulations are used to predict the effect of proposed method and power requirements in reservoir scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is a novel, inexpensive, and environmentally friendly solution for production improvement in oil, gas, geothermal, and groundwater reservoirs. Fracking/stimulation is a required step after drilling to increase permeability and get access to the trapped geofluid in sedimentary and rock formations. This method provides an alternative or complementary reservoir permeability enhancement solution to current high-pressure water/acid injection-based methods such as hydraulic or acid fracking. In this sense, our proposed innovation will allow for an economical permeability increase without water contamination and induced seismic activities. Furthermore, this method will alleviate the demand in water-stressed areas. The global hydraulic fracturing market alone is expected to reach $66 billion by 2022 due to the increasing demand for hydrocarbon-based resources in which the US itself accounts for 70% of the total increase in global oil growth capacity. Additionally, there are 248 operating and 168 under development geothermal power plants which add approximately $3.7 billion to the reservoir stimulation market.

This I-Corps project identifies the commercial potential for developing a novel Electric Reservoir Stimulation (ERS) method that increases reservoir permeability for petroleum and geothermal applications, without requiring pumping material into the subsurface. During a seven-week program, the team conducted an intensive customer discovery and interview process accomplishing more than 100 interviews with potential customers. Significant results included identification of customer segments, discovery of several pivots necessary to target these segments, and identification of a value proposition for these customer segments. Customer discovery continued after the training period that included other markets in addition to the one that was intensely investigated during the training period.

The team conducted a series of laboratory experiments and numerical simulations to hypothesize and validate ideas about the capabilities of the technology based on the feedback and comments we received from the customer discovery interviews. The team designed a bottom hole assembly (BHA) tool and a conveyance system through collaborations with industry experts and end-users and leaders whom we met and interviewed previously. A patent for the core technology was published recently and three more patents have been filed.

The company was also accepted into two energy accelerator programs since the I-Corps 7-week cohort ended. The company?s long-term vision is to adapt the technology to the traditional and enhanced geothermal systems which are important to the decarbonization of our environment and economy on multiple fronts.


Last Modified: 12/26/2021
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
